ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Got better at literary analysis and deducing themes from texts. Gained insight on what the epic genre even is and how close & far it is from that of the novel.
I developed better writing skills, as well as a more cautious and rigorous approach to literary analysis.
I learned about how literature both evolves and stays the same.
I was able to read and engage with some of the most important works ever written. I improved my writing skills and gained a better knowledge of the western canon as a whole.
I became a much better writer and learned how to read very difficult texts. With my writing, Professor Markovits actually challenged my ideas and tendencies in writing, and I was much better for it.
I learned how to track literary throughlines through history, and how to identify the characteristics of the epic genre. Also general writing and reading skills.
I saw what literary analysis could look like and how works thread throughout a canon.
This class taught me more about how to read and discuss novels than I ever knew before.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength - very, very good reading list.

Weakness - this is inevitable, but...the readings were very long, sometimes hard to keep up with syllabus.
More time would of course have been nice but being rushed comes with the territory.
The structure of the reading and the class discussions were very good. However, there was not much variety as to the nature of class time.

strengths: extraordinary selection of works, great feedback from Professor Markovits, engaging discussion in class
weaknesses: we go through works with a lot of speed, so it can sometimes feel overwhelming. I know that's the nature of the class, but especially with "Don Quixote," I feel like we flew through the text in a bit of a whirlwind.

This course allows you to read some truly incredible works of literature and place them in dialogue with each other. The people who take this course are genuinely interested in literature, so class discussions were always insightful and generative.Since the amount of reading we had to get through in the semester was fairly high, I sometimes felt as if we rushed through certain parts of the books; Ulysses, in particular, was difficult to read quickly and still understand. At the same time, I genuinely loved all the books we read, and I wouldn't suggest removing any of them in order to make more time to discuss the others.

Fantastic course. Professor Markovits is great, and the readings are really interesting. They're pretty heavy too, but that's not really a weakness of the coursetake it if you have time to read a lot, and it will be very fulfilling.
Great selection of books.

One strength is the texts, which are definitely challenging but all incredible in their own different ways. The other is Prof. Markovits, who teaches the class with incredible rigor, energy, and generosity. There are no real weaknesses as long as you are prepared to do the reading.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Seminar translated well to virtual format. Sometimes class discussion was dominated by individuals solely because the instructor saw their hand first...I suspect that this would have been less of a problem in-person.

Considering the circumstances, I think this course did the best it possibly could have. Of course, in-person class would be the ideal, but the virtual classroom worked very well. I did not feel like my learning was compromised at all because of the Zoom format.

Class discussions helped keep me engaged, but I wish we'd kept both sections open instead of just one. It was difficult to have a larger seminar over Zoom; I would often have an idea but not be able to share it because so many other people who also be raising their hands.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. It is truly an excellent reading list. And some of the texts are very hard to approach without the guidance of this course.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in developing a tangible connection between some of the greatest books ever written, although one must be prepared for a large amount of reading.
Yes if they want to read the books its a good way to do it.
Yes, it provides a wide scope of knowledge and insight.

Yes, I definitely would. I loved the books we read and feel a lot more confident about my knowledge of western literature. The discussion was engaging every single day and Professor Markovits is excellent as she guides us through the works.

As long as you know what you're getting into, absolutely. It's a bomb reading list with a teacher that will make sure you discuss and write genuinely complex ideas. However, it is a lot of work. And the professor isn't an easy grader(although not extremely harsh). I also found the exam a little difficult and this is one of the only english classes that still has an exam. I was just short on time when writing an in-class essay. Otherwise, though I'm just proud of getting through this class. I just love these books and the discussions we had. Very much worth it.

If you love to read, then please take this course! It'll allow you to read some incredible works of literature that you were probably planning to read anyways but with the scaffolding of a formal course. I don't think I would have gotten as much out of the some of the textsparticularly Ulyssesif I hadn't had class discussions to supplement my initial understanding of the readings. The reading load is fairly heavy, so don't take this course if you're just looking for an easy credit.
Yes. Great for anyone who wants a well-rounded understanding of a lot of foundational texts.
Yes! I highly recommend this course to read and discuss with Professor Markovits some timeless writings.

Yes. Prof. Markovits is simply the best English teacher I have ever had. 

She is thoughtful, precise, and generous in her curriculum, her (virtual) classroom, and her feedback. She both justifies and challenges the existence of a course on European Epic. She grounds our conversations with emotional and thematic stakes that feel powerful and urgent. She is brimming with enthusiasm for our discussions and our contributions. Somehow she can keep us lingering on a single moment in a five hundred page novel for half of a class, and yet when it's time to move onto the next one we feel like we've done the whole text justice.

I am so grateful for the opportunity to read alongside her. If the books on syllabus appeal to you, don't think twice  take this class.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: no other modes
none

extras.title:
ENGL 130 01/LITR 169 01
        Epic in European Lit Tradition
